newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia has first post-reform monthly price fall.
newsitem.headline: Russia has first post-reform monthly price fall.

text.p: Russian consumer prices fell in August for the first time since economic reforms began in 1992, official figures showed Wednesday.
The state statistics committee said prices fell 0.2 percent in August, after a rise of 0.7 percent in July.
Year-on-year inflation for August is not yet available, but the committee said consumer prices had risen 16.1 percent since the start of the year.
If the current negative price trend continued, annual inflation could be as low as 15 percent, it said. Consumer prices rose 131 percent year-on-year in December 1995.
Russian prices rises are traditionally lower in summer due to lower food prices. But the decline will be welcome news to a government under pressure on other economic fronts.
Tax collection is running well behind schedule and the government will face a tough battle to get its tight 1997 budget through a parliament dominated by communists and other conservatives.
The budget envisages a deficit of 3.3 percent of gross domestic product, after a forecast 3.85 percent gap this year.
The International Monetary Fund postponed handing over the July tranche of a three-year $10 billion loan to Russia because of concern about Moscow's ability to meet the 1996 budget.
But the money was handed over last month and the IMF is expected to approve the August tranche of the loan soon.
Officials working with the Russian finance ministry say the IMF also revised upward its target for the Russian budget deficit to 5.25 percent of gross domestic product, from 4 percent.
Russia and the IMF use different methodology to calculate the budget deficit.
